Priority: I personally will be also working on my van buildout and boat projects at the farm, in addition to art.

Gaining new members: we should all agree/vote on new members not only a few people deciding, also weigh what they will bring to the community (both ours and the public offerings)... they after-all will be our family.
I'd like to see building classes from some of our people who know how to do framing, construction etc (which there really isn't any classes of that I know of - I'd take them!).

I like the idea of structured classes where people come, take a class and go, and less like the idea of being open to the public all the time where people are coming and going (especially during covid) and where things will go missing... but that's a personal preference, and I'm kinda an introvert sometimes. I think we should strike a balance between a community resource and a free-for-all of random people visiting all the time/just walking on in and borrowing things, where the makers are at the epicenter of a constant stream of people. I also think we should have a calendar of events that is very clear what is happening when and other times when the farm is not open to the public.
The Makerfarm is an outdoor workspace and urban farm
The Makerfarm community is passionate about sharing our skills.
Our members are talented and skilled in their crafts.
With the do-it-yourself spirit that is at the core of our organization, we all have the opportunity to learn something new, and all have the ability to share.
We dance, garden, blacksmith, sew, and woodwork.
We hatch baby chicks and raise them to maturity.
We hope to instill the maker mindset in every person we reach.
We can all fix things, and we can all make something out of nothing.
The Makerfarm community is part of the larger Bay Area community.
In the critical early months of shelter-in-place, many of our members stepped up to make PPE for hospital workers and first responders.
Since Makerfarm is an outdoor space, we have been one of the few safe places to facilitate hands on learning experiences and promote science education during the pandemic.

We are also an official Alameda Animal Shelter, specializing in rehoming chickens from Alameda Animal Control, and our animals have brought immense joy to innumerable individuals as their paths cross with ours.

Thanks to our food redistribution infrastructure and composting/garden soil production we have been able to share critical resources with bay area residents and beyond, not to mention, keeping valuable resources out of the waste stream.
The Makerfarm promotes and embodies the principles of sustainability, zero-waste, and local resilience.
